Practical Design Studio 1 ","description":"

Practical Design Studio 1 sets the foundation for the practice of design thinking in the built environment with particular emphasis on research-led design inquiry as well as pursuing expansive exploration of ideas through iterative and reflective design techniques.

The design brief at the basis of the course introduces you to the key phases, processes, materials and elements of the built environment from the macro scale of landscape and architecture through to the micro scales of interiors and industrial design and the digital potential of computational design.

The course will encourage a design response that is critical, curious and inquisitive leading to design proposals that speculate on the future relationships between people and the built environment.

contentlets.description:
Practical Design Studio 1 sets the foundation for the practice of design thinking in the built environment with particular emphasis on research-led design inquiry as well as pursuing expansive exploration of ideas through iterative and reflective design techniques.

The design brief at the basis of the course introduces you to the key phases, processes, materials and elements of the built environment from the macro scale of landscape and architecture through to the micro scales of interiors and industrial design and the digital potential of computational design.

The course will encourage a design response that is critical, curious and inquisitive leading to design proposals that speculate on the future relationships between people and the built environment.

Design History and Theory","description":"

In this course we will explore connections between the disciplines of architecture, interior architecture, landscape architecture, industrial design and computation design. We will investigate sites, ideas, concepts and technologies of historic and present-day significance and the way in which their principles have survived and evolved over a long period of time.


The history of design thinking offers insight into a human being, who feels an affinity with a city at all scales from landscape, street, building, room, as well as the fundamental elements of a column, door, window, ornament, chair, door handle and right down to product and object.

• This is a formative assessment leading into assignment 2

• A student submits 3 tasks, each comprising a text and accompanying sketches. The drawings and texts involve describing the way a person may appreciate a designed object.

• Word limits with drawings - 100 words/task. See the task details in the Assessment Guide.

• Footnotes and a bibliography are not required for this assignment. Assessment considers an individual student’s work and provides a mark that will count as 20% of the course total. The 3 tasks are very brief and simple. Each is worth one-third of the 20%

Feedback will be provided via the LMS course page.

Practical Design Studio 2","description":"

“When I’m working on a problem, I never think about its beauty, I just think about how to solve the problem, but when I finish it, if the solution is not beautiful, I know it’s wrong.” - Buckminster Fuller cited in Darling, David J. (2004). The Universal Book of Mathematics. John Wiley and Sons, Page 34.  


The Built Environment is made up of a range of disciplines, each of which has a particular focus. However, it is common to work across or to collaborate with multiple disciplines. This studio asks you to design a range of interventions, beginning with an object, then a building and finally designing a landscape response. You are encouraged to think creatively about how you integrate your interventions with the existing site and the surrounding context. Each intervention should address challenges and opportunities identified through a thorough site analysis to create a design response that is functional, beautiful and enhances the site.

Architectural Composition and Modelling","description":"

This course builds on capabilities and skills from DPDE1002 - Communication in the Built Environment to develop a further range of communication skills specific to Design, Architecture and Computational Design. You will explore intermediate analogue and intermediate-advanced digital representation techniques in a suite of software with a digital and physical output. Emphasis will be placed on an iterative, theoretical and practical approach to making as a means of spatial exploration, research and articulation of design environments.

Building Environments and Technics 1 ","description":"

Building Environments and Technics 1 is an introduction to the structural, constructional and physical principles of the built environment.


The course will investigate the significance of building materials and the perception of spaces in relation to their use along with the construction of primary building elements including foundations, floors, walls, openings, roofs and stairs and their application to the built environment.


The interface between architecture and interior will be explored through the principles of structure, substrate and skin with a particular emphasis on the role of materiality in construction and fabrication technologies.


You will learn to read and produce documentation and models of a technical level of execution and accuracy in line with industry standards.

contentlets.keywords: building environments and technics,building environments,technics,documentation,construction technologies,construction principles,structural principles,material principles,building construction
contentlets.description:
Building Environments and Technics 1 is an introduction to the structural, constructional and physical principles of the built environment.

The course will investigate the significance of building materials and the perception of spaces in relation to their use along with the construction of primary building elements including foundations, floors, walls, openings, roofs and stairs and their application to the built environment.

The interface between architecture and interior will be explored through the principles of structure, substrate and skin with a particular emphasis on the role of materiality in construction and fabrication technologies.

You will learn to read and produce documentation and models of a technical level of execution and accuracy in line with industry standards.
contentlets.title: Building Environments and Technics 1

Science and Environment","description":"

This course introduces you to the design strategies and scientific understanding needed to minimize buildings’ impact on natural resources and the environment. It includes life-cycle thinking in architectural design, a history of environmental design concepts in architecture, understanding and responding to climate, design innovation, solar architecture, building fabric performance and wind, ventilation, and cooling. In completing the course, you will master the basic techniques to reduce building-related carbon emissions and enhance human comfort through climate-sensitive design. In addition, you will gain the ability to analyze climatic and geomorphological context to optimize building design for sun, temperature, wind, human metabolism, and perception.

Interior Architecture Critical Perspectives","description":"

Interior Architecture Critical Perspectives builds on your foundational study in DPDE1003 Design History and Theory 1.  The course focuses on interior space as a site of dwelling and introduces you to historical, cultural and theoretical perspectives on the concept of dwelling and its material constructions.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"ba1359b81b0ab010d5fb0fabdc4bcb92","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Case Study ","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

This assessment requires you to research one case study from the periods that have been covered in the course to date. 

This task aims to develop your skills in academic research, locating, analysing and referencing academic sources, and thoughtfully curating research to form an argument. It requires you to develop and understanding of historical approaches to interiors in their relevant contexts.

Feedback on individual assessments will be delivered in writing via LMS and general feedback orally in-class by the tutor. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"321359b81b0ab010d5fb0fabdc4bcb95","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3a1359b81b0ab010d5fb0fabdc4bcb94","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ba1359b81b0ab010d5fb0fabdc4bcb93","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"431359b81b0ab010d5fb0fabdc4bcba6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Engagement Portfolio","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

The engagement portfolio is a series of tasks that demonstrate your engagement with the learning content and activities of the course. These take the form of responding to the readings, quizzes, satisfactory engagement in the tutorial exercises and evidence of peer collaboration. 

Aims: This task aims to develop your ability to engage with content, learning and peers, as well as responding to the ideas of others and communicate your thoughts and position in relation to the content presented in the course.

General feedback is provided orally in-class as well as in writing via LMS for specific items of the portfolio. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"321359b81b0ab010d5fb0fabdc4bcb95","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3a1359b81b0ab010d5fb0fabdc4bcb94","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"3a1359b81b0ab010d5fb0fabdc4bcb95","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ba1359b81b0ab010d5fb0fabdc4bcb93","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"761359b81b0ab010d5fb0fabdc4bcb98","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Critical Analysis","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

This assessment requires you to document and then analyze your current dwelling in light of the ideas, theories and precedents studied throughout the course. This assessment takes the form of a written and graphic analysis as well as an in-class presentation. 

This task aims to develop your ability to place and communicate your own work in a critical, historical design context. It requires you to trace the influences of historical interior practices and theory on your own design thinking.

Feedback on individual assessments will be delivered in writing via LMS.

contentlets.description: Interior Architecture Critical Perspectives builds on your foundational study in DPDE1003 Design History and Theory 1.  The course focuses on interior space as a site of dwelling and introduces you to historical, cultural and theoretical perspectives on the concept of dwelling and its material constructions.
contentlets.title: Interior Architecture Critical Perspectives

Industrial Design Studio","description":"

In this course you will explore the creative processes that are specific to the design of products in Industrial Design and prepare for entry into the Industrial Design program. In this studio-based course, you will build upon your previous studies of 2D and 3D design, hand sketching, hand modelling and computer aided drawing and modelling. You will develop new skills as you embark upon product design projects. These projects guide you through the generation and expression of original product ideas in response to a design brief and present these using visual communication and model making techniques.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"b1f31df81b0ab010d5fb0fabdc4bcb23","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Design Project 1: Lite Wire","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

The assessment task is a design and making project using steel wire as the material. A detailed brief will be provided in the Assessment Guide at the start of the term, outlining the category of object to be made, constraints that apply to size, purpose and material selection. Assessment criteria linked to CLOs will be set out in a marking rubric, included with the assignment brief.

Submission requirements will be: 

  1. An online process illustrated process journal kept up to date and available weekly for presentation to class.
  2. A final model, exhibited in studio and photographed for online submission.
  3. Technical drawings submitted online on completion of the project.

Formative feedback will be provided weekly in class or online by tutors and comments/contributions invited from peers. Summative feedback will be provided by tutors with separate marks for:

  1. Process - based on the record of the design process in the process journal, on completion 
  2. Final Design - as communicated by the model and technical drawing.

A written feedback comment will be provided via the course LMS page, with reference to the stated assessment criteria.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f1f31df81b0ab010d5fb0fabdc4bcb25","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f9f31df81b0ab010d5fb0fabdc4bcb24","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f9f31df81b0ab010d5fb0fabdc4bcb25","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"fdf31df81b0ab010d5fb0fabdc4bcb23","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"39f31df81b0ab010d5fb0fabdc4bcb28","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Design Project 2: Good Sheet","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

This assessment task is a design and making project - to design and prototype an office product made largely of one type of sheet material. Choice of material could include cardboard, polystyrene or acrylic plastic sheet material, aluminum or steel sheet. A detailed brief will be provided in the Assessment Guide at the start of term, outlining the category of object to be designed, constraints that apply to size, purpose, material selection and finish. Assessment criteria linked to CLOs will be set out in a marking rubric, included with the assignment brief.

Submission requirements will be: 

  1. An online process illustrated process journal kept up to date and available weekly for presentation to class.
  2. A final model, exhibited in studio and/or photographed for online submission.
  3. Technical drawings submitted online on completion of the project In this project knowledge of manufacturing production methods is expected to be evident in the drawings.

Formative feedback will be provided weekly in class or online by tutors and comments/contributions invited from peers. Summative feedback will be provided by tutors with separate marks for:

  1. Process - based on the record of the design process in the process journal, on completion 
  2. Final Design - as communicated by the model and technical drawing.

A written feedback comment will be provided by tutors via the course LMS page, with reference to the stated assessment criteria.

Feedback will be provided via the course LMS page.

Introduction to Landscape Architecture and Analysis","description":"

This course introduces you to the concept of landscapes as inter-related processes and systems.  It focusses on the human, biotic and abiotic characteristics of landscapes in urban and non-urban settings. 


You will focus on plants and their role in ecology and landscape architecture through a design and botanical classification. You develop a vocabulary of planting elements and an ability to design with plants to achieve specific spatial qualities.  By analyzing small-scale planting designs and developing a personal herbarium, you lay down the foundation of horticultural knowledge and develop skills in planting design and design communication. 


This course includes two field trips within the Sydney Region.

Digital Technologies develops your abilities for applying technical and theoretical skills through computational design workflows and processes.
